caption:
This photograph captures a close-up view of a rough, textured surface that appears to be an aerial or satellite image of a rugged terrain, possibly a volcanic area or a dried-up riverbed. The details show intricately patterned formations of the terrain, featuring a mix of lighter and darker patches, with many grooves and ridges providing a complex, interconnected pattern.

The texture is generally bumpy and uneven, with sections that look like flowing material, possibly indicating previous movement or molten activity if volcanic. Shades vary from light brown to darker brown tones, suggesting different mineral compositions or varying depths. The overall appearance gives an impression of a desolate, uninhabited terrain where natural processes dominate the landscape.

No human activities, people, or vegetation are apparent; the focus is solely on the natural geological features, highlighting their raw beauty and geological complexity. The image provides a detailed glimpse into the natural patterns and forces that shape such landscapes, possibly useful for geological or environmental studies.
title: Partially digested sewage entering tanks for secondary treatment at the newton creek sewage treatment plant in Brooklyn, New York.  In the metropolitan region there are 31 major drainage areas discharge two billion gallons of waste water each day into rivers and bays.  Three areas in New York city discharge untreated waste into New York harbour and the Hudson River
